titleStmt.title: An integrated transcriptomic and proteomic analysis reveals toxin arsenal of a novel Antarctic jellyfish Cyanea sp

affiliation.orgName: Faculty of Naval Medicine, Second Military Medical University (Naval Medical University)

analytic.title: An integrated transcriptomic and proteomic analysis reveals toxin arsenal of a novel Antarctic jellyfish Cyanea sp

biblStruct.note: Received 28 June 2019; Received in revised form 17 July 2019; Accepted 7 August 2019

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Jellyfish Cyanea sp. Transcriptome Proteome Toxin Antarctic

abstract.p: Jellyfish is a common toxic zooplankton in ocean. We successfully captured a kind of jellyfish 200 m underwater in Antarctica, and identified it as a jellyfish Cyanea sp. through morphological examination and MT-CO1 phylogenetic analysis. A total of 40,468 unigenes were harvested through transcriptome sequencing. We also successfully annotated 12,955 (32.01%) unigenes with the NR database, 10,882 (26.89%) unigenes with the SWISSPROT database, 4951 (12.23%) unigenes with the GO database, and 4901 (12.11%) unigenes with the KEGG database. In the proteomic analysis, a total of 11,159 peptides and 2630 proteins were harvested using the constructed transcriptome as the database. A number of 771 (29.31%) and 841 (31.98%) proteins were annotated against the GO and KEGG database, respectively. Moreover, a number of 29 toxic proteins matched from the 145 toxin-related unigenes were successfully screened, including 6 metalloproteinases, 4 phospholipases, 2 serine proteases, 1 serine protease inhibitor, 7 toxin-related venom and 9 other toxins. Our study is the first to identify a polar jellyfish Cyanea sp. with transcriptomics and proteomics, and these data can further serve as a public database for the identification of potential polar jellyfish-derived lead compounds feasibly functioning in the cold environment. Significance: With increasing discussions on marine biodiversity and global warming, polar species have gradually become a focus for research. To the best of our knowledge, there is only one paper in pubMed about the mitochondrial genome of the Antarctic stalked jellyfish Haliclystus antarcticus Pfeffer. In this study, we captured a type of jellyfish (named BD-4) from the Southern Ocean (60°29′57" S, 52°11′44"W) on the scientific expedition ship "Xue Long" at the end of 2016. Although the samples were stored and transported by the ship at only −20°C for more than two month, we successfully extracted the total RNA, and performed molecular species identification and combined analyses of de novo transcriptomics and proteomics. In addition to conventional bioinformatics techniques such as GO and KEGG annotation, we screened and listed toxic proteins, aligned the sequences, simulated three-dimensional structures and performed molecular phylogenetic analysis for typical components, including metalloproteinase and serine proteinase. Our study is the first to identify a polar jellyfish Cyanea sp. with de novo transcriptomics and proteomics, and these data can further serve as a public database for the identification of potential polar jellyfish-derived lead compounds. 1. Introduction The oceans cover approximately 71% of the area of the earth [1], but only 16% of all currently named species live in marine environments [2]. With the increasing discovery of marine species [3], aquatic organisms are an important and mysterious target for scientific

div.p: researchers. As among the most ancient marine organisms, jellyfish show strong vitality and wide adaptability, which has resulted in the significant growth of the number of jellyfish in coastal areas from late spring into the early autumn in recent decades globally [4,5], greatly impacting human production and life and causing environmental [6] and health problems [7]. Although dozens of papers about the jellyfish transcriptome and proteome have been published [8][9][10], only types of jellyfish with large abundances, lethal toxins or special biological characters such as Chironex fleckeri [10,11], Aurelia aurita [12], Irukandji jellyfish [13,14], Physalia physalis [15,16] and Cyanea nozakii [17], are research hotspots today. However, there still remains a massive amount of potential data to be generated, considering that there are 456 different subfamilies of jellyfish, according to the World Register of Marine Species (WoRMS) on 5th March 2017 [2].

Antarctica, the southernmost continent with the coldest temperatures, is completely surrounded by oceans, in which only specific organisms and animals can live [18,19]. With increasing discussions on marine biodiversity [20] and global warming, polar species have gradually become a focus for research. To the best of our knowledge, there is only one paper in pubMed about the mitochondrial genome of the Antarctic stalked jellyfish Haliclystus antarcticus Pfeffer [21]. Notably, we captured a type of jellyfish (named BD-4) from the Southern Ocean (60°29′57" S, 52°11′44"W) on the scientific expedition ship "Xue Long" at the end of 2016. Although the samples were stored and transported by the ship at only −20°C for more than two month, we successfully extracted the total RNA, which is a difficult achievement even with fresh jellyfish samples. In this study, we performed molecular species identification and combined analyses of de novo transcriptomics and proteomics. In addition to conventional bioinformatics techniques such as GO and KEGG annotation, we screened and listed toxic proteins, aligned the sequences, simulated three-dimensional structures and performed molecular phylogenetic analysis for typical components, including metalloproteinase and serine proteinase. Our study is the first to identify a polar jellyfish Cyanea sp. with de novo transcriptomics and proteomics, and these data can further serve as a public database for the identification of potential polar jellyfish-derived lead compounds.

div.head: Jellyfish collection
div.p: The polar Jellyfish were captured 200 m underwater using vertical netting from Antarctica (60°29′57" S, 52°11′44"W) on December 31st, 2016, by the Chinese scientific expedition ship "Xue Long", which belongs to the Polar Research Institute of China. The jellyfish was sent back to Shanghai by ship in February 2017.

div.head: MT-CO1 DNA sequencing and phylogenetic analysis 2.2.1. MT-CO1 DNA extraction and sequencing
div.p: Jellyfish DNA was extracted using a genomic DNA purification kit (TIANGEN). Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was used to amplify the segment of mitochondrion-encoded cytochrome c oxidase subunit I (MT-CO1). The universal primers were designed based on the conserved segment of the MT-CO1 gene sequence. After the reaction, the PCR product was subjected to 1% agarose gel electrophoresis to confirm the PCR amplification fragment, which was then recycled and sequenced by an AxyPrep DNA gel extraction Kit (Personalbio) and DNA sequencer (ABI3730-XL) [22,23].

div.head: Phylogenetic sequence analysis
div.p: MT-CO1 sequences were collected from the NCBI nucleotide database (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nuccore/). The evolutionary tree was constructed by the Maximum Likelihood method based on the General Time Reversible model [24]. The bootstrap consensus tree inferred from 1000 replicates was taken to represent the evolutionary history of the taxa analyzed. Branches corresponding to partitions reproduced in < 50% bootstrap replicates were collapsed. The percentages of replicate trees in which the associated taxa clustered together in the bootstrap test (1000 replicates) are shown next to the branches [25]. Initial tree(s) for the heuristic search were obtained automatically by applying Neighbor-Joining and BioNJ algorithms to a matrix of pairwise distances estimated using the Maximum Composite Likelihood (MCL) approach and then selecting the topology with the superior log likelihood value. A discrete Gamma distribution was used to model evolutionary rate differences among sites (5 categories (+G, parameter = 0.8671)). The analysis involved 65 nucleotide sequences. All positions containing gaps and missing data were eliminated. There were a total of 413 positions in the final dataset. Evolutionary analyses were conducted in MEGA7 [26].

div.head: RNA sequencing
div.p: Total RNA was isolated from the whole jellyfish. Magnetic beads with oligodT were used to combine the polyA of the mRNA for purifying the mRNA from the total RNA. The mRNA was then mixed with fragmentation buffer to obtain short fragments of 200-300 bp. The fragments were used to synthesize first-strand cDNA with random primers, and the first-strand cDNA was transformed into double-strand cDNA using RNase H and DNA polymerase I. Fragments of desirable lengths (200-300 bp) were purified using the QIAquick PCR Extraction Kit (Qiagen, Valencia, CA, USA). Under the function of 3′-5′ exonuclease and polymerase, the protruding termini of the DNA fragments were end-repaired. Base "A" was induced at the 3′ end of DNA fragments, so base "T" at the 3′ end of the adapters could complement the induced base "A". The end-repaired DNA fragments were ligated with sequencing adapters through A and T complementary base pairing. AMPure XP beads (Beckman Coulter, Shanghai, China) were used to remove unsuitable fragments. The sequencing library was constructed using polymerase chain reaction (PCR). The multiplexed cDNA libraries were checked using PicoGreen (Quantifluor™ST fluorometer E6090, Promega, CA, USA) and fluorospectrophotometry (QuantiT PicoGreen dsDNA Assay Kit; Invitrogen, P7589) and quantified with the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer (Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer, Agilent, 2100; Agilent High Sensitivity DNA Kit, Agilent, 5067-4626). The synthesized cDNA libraries were normalized to 2 nM. The sequencing library was gradually diluted and quantified to 4-5 pM and sequenced using the Illumina HiSeq platform to obtain raw data.

To ensure the quality of the follow-up information analysis, it is necessary to filter raw data and to generate high-quality data (clean data). Data filtering standards include (1) removing the adapter sequence and (2) quality filtering. Cutadapt (Version 1.2.1) was used to remove the 3 'end of the adapter sequence. The criteria removed sequences coinciding with at least 10 bases of the AGATCGGAAG sequence, allowing a 10% base error rate. Quality control was performed after the Illumina sequencing with FastQC software (http://www. bioinformatics.babraham.ac.uk/projects/fastqc), which is a commonly used quality inspection tool. The quality was evaluated with four criteria: single base quality, base content distribution, GC content distribution and sequence base quality. Only those fractions that were more than Q20 were considered high quality reads and retained. The raw data of RNA sequences were submitted to the Sequence Read Archievew (https://submit.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/subs) with the accession number PRJNA553312.

div.head: De novo transcript assembly
div.p: Trinity was used with default parameters to reconstruct transcripts de novo, without a specific reference genome [27]. The software (r20140717, kmer 25 bp) consists of three separate software modules, namely, Inchworm (assembling the original reads of RNAseq into contigs), Chrysalis (classifying contigs and then building Bruijn graphs for each class) and Butterfly (processing the Bruijn graphs, looking for paths based on reads and pairs of reads in the figure), that process the RNAseq data in order. First, a short read library of K-mer lengths was constructed using high-quality sequences, and the short reads were then extended by overlaps among reads (length of K-mer-1) to obtain the initial spliced contig sequence. The contig sequences were clustered by overlaps among contigs. A de Bruijn graph was constructed for each cluster, and, according to the read support situation of each de Bruijn graph branch, the transcript sequence was restored. K-mer refers to a nucleotide sequence of length K that is continuously cut and divided by bases. A contig is a larger fragment assembled by overlapped reads, whereas a transcript is formed by the splicing of contigs.

div.head: Annotation of transcripts
div.p: Unigenes were obtained for gene expression annotation. The databases used for gene function annotation were the NCBI nonredundant (NR) (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/protein/), SwissProt (http://web. expasy.org/docs/swiss-prot_guideline.html), Gene Ontology (GO, http://geneontology.org/), Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genome (KEGG, http://www.kegg.jp/), and evolutionary genealogy of genes: Nonsupervised Orthologous Groups (eggNOG, http://eggnog.embl.de/ version_4.0.beta/) databases.

div.head: Protein extraction and digestion
div.p: The jellyfish was sonicated in cold lysis buffer (8.0 M urea, 100 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.0), 1 × protease inhibitor). After centrifugation, the supernatant was mixed with 1 M DTT (dithiothreitol) and kept at 37°C for 1 h. Then, 1 M IAA (iodoacetamide) was added and reacted at room temperature for 1 h in the dark. After centrifugation, the supernatant was mixed with UA (8 M urea, 100 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0) solution followed by centrifugation twice. The supernatant was discarded, whereas the pellet was resuspended in 50 mM NH 4 HCO 3 solution. Then, trypsin (trypsin: proteins = 1:50) was added, and the samples were digested at 37°C for 16 h.

div.head: LC-MS/MS analysis
div.p: Each sample was analyzed by liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry/mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) using an Orbitrap Fusion Lumos mass spectrometer coupled to an Easy nLC/Ultimate 3000 nano-HPLC chromatography system (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA) with buffer A 0.1% formic acid solution and buffer B 0.1% formic acid in acetonitrile aqueous solution. The column was first equilibrated with 95% buffer A. Samples were loaded from the autosampler to the C18 trap column (3 μm, 0.10 μm × 20 mm) and separated by an analytical C18 column (1.9 μm, 0.15 μm × 120 mm) at a flow rate of 600 nl/min. Primary parent ion scanning was performed in the orbitrap after peptide fragmentation. At MasterScan the scanning range was set to 300-1400 (m/z), the Orbitrap resolution was set to 120,000, the automatic gain control target was set to 5 × 10 5 , and the maximum injection time was set to 50 ms. HCD activation type was used in secondary spectrograms (ddMSnScan) with a Iontrap, a collision energy of 30%, a stepped collision energy of 5%, an automatic gain control target of 5 × 10 3 , and a maximum injection time of 35 ms. The dynamic exclusion time was set to 18 s. The positive ion mode and the negative ion mode were separately employed with the spray voltage of mass spectrometer at 2000 V and 600 V, and the spray temperature of 320°C for peptides. Proteomic datasets were deposited in ProteomeXchange (http://www.ebi.ac.uk/pride/archive) with the accession number PXD014641.

div.head: Database search and bioinformatics analysis
div.p: Mass spectrometry analysis of raw data for the RAW file was conducted with Proteome Discoverer software (Thermo Scientific), and the de novo transcriptome was utilized as a reference. The search parameters were set as follows: enzyme = trypsin, max missed cleavages = 2, fixed modifications = carbamidomethyl (C), variable modifications = oxidation (M), acetyl (Protein N-term), peptide mass tolerance = ± 15 ppm, fragment mass tolerance = 20 mmu, peptide confidence = high. The GO analysis of the identified proteins covered three subdomains: biological processes (BP), cellular components (CC) and molecular functions (MF). Pathway annotation was conducted by KEGG. Multisequence alignment analysis was performed using BioEdit (Version: 7.0.5.3) under default parameters. The phylogenetic tree was constructed using the Neighbor-Joining method by MEGA. The screened proteins were modeled in 3D by SWISS-MODEL (https:// swissmodel.expasy.org/) and displayed by Discovery studio 4.5.

div.head: Species identification
div.p: Taking the research background of jellyfish and the lack of polar jellyfish information into account, we commissioned scientists from the 'Xuelong' scientific research vessel of the China Polar Research Center and collected a type of polar jellyfish during the Antarctic expedition (Fig. 1A). This jellyfish has the typical morphological characters of jellyfish with complete body parts, including a transparent umbrella, tentacles, oral arms and a brown gastric pouch. We first performed the molecular identification of the captured polar jellyfish by PCR amplification, sequencing and alignment of mtDNA cytochrome c oxidase subunit I (MT-COI, CO1), which functions as a catalytic subunit and is a common molecule for species identification because of its high conservation. Sequences sharing > 97% of the CO1 sequence identity are generally considered to represent the same species [28]. Use of the online tool BLASTn (nucleotide to nucleotide) from NCBI (https://blast. ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi) indicated that the most highly aligned CO1 sequence, with an identity of 98.90%, is from a species of Mollusca Cf. Laternula sp., which is obviously an incorrect identification and can be easily ruled out from the morphological assessment. However, starting with the second aligned sequence from the jellyfish Cyanea tzetlinii, the subsequent 99 aligned sequences are all from the cnidarian group with a scale of identities of 83.15-84.70%. Phylogenetic analysis was then constructed with 6 typical species, namely, Cf. Laternula sp.

Chrysaora sp. (KY611265.1, 84.54%), and Sanderia malayensis (KY611267.1, 82.93%) ( Fig. 1B). Except for the most aligned CO1 sequence from Cf. Laternula sp., the closest CO1 sequence is from the jellyfish Stomolophus sp., with an identity of 84.70%, followed by C. tzetlinii and C. capillata, with identities of 85.33% and 83.46%, respectively. Since 60 of the 100 top aligned CO1 sequences are hits from Cyanea, our preliminary speculation is that the captured Antarctic jellyfish belongs to the genus Cyanea.

The online tool BLASTx (nucleotide to protein) was then used to transform the CO1 nucleotide sequence to a protein sequence, which was then subjected to an online alignment against the non-redundant (NR) database. We did not obtain an alignment with the CO1 protein sequence from Cf. Laternula sp. Instead, the most aligned protein sequence, with an identity of 98.10%, is from the jellyfish Cyanea sp.. The top 100 aligned sequences are all derived from jellyfish and have much higher identities (91.78-98.10%) than the DNA CO1 sequence alignments. This can be explained by the degeneracy and wobble phenomenon, which results in a looser alignment between nucleotides than between proteins. Sequence alignment shows that the identities of the two CO1 protein sequences from C. capillata and C. tzetlinii with the BD-4 CO1 sequence were 97.63% and 96.80%, respectively. In comparison to the CO1 sequence from Cyanea tzetlinii, the protein from the polar jellyfish displays three mutations, namely, F166 L, M173 L and L178 M, and lacks several amino acids (or segments), including K 1~A21 , W 78 , L 101~L114 , W 122 , V 182~A200 , and W 233 (Fig. 1C). Phylogenetic analysis was conducted with 7 typical species, namely, C. capillata (AJE61222.1, 97.26%), C. tzetlinii (AJE61240.1, 96.80%), Nemopilema nomurai (ACB29734.1, 93.02%), Phacellophora camtschatica (ACZ67472.1, 93.15%), Aurelia sp. (ACZ67464.1, 93.15%), Chrysaora pacifica (BAW87744.1, 93.61%) and Pelagia noctiluca (ACZ67467.1, 93.61%) ( Fig. 1D). Consistent with the sequence identities, the species closest to BD-4 are the jellyfish C. capillata and C. tzetlinii, followed by N. nomurai, P. camtschatica and A. sp. Moreover, a total of 22 CO1 sequences from Cyanea aligned with the BD-4 sequence, making Cyanea the most frequently hit genus and supporting our conclusion that the captured BD-4 jellyfish can be identified as an Antarctic jellyfish Cyanea sp..

div.head: Quality control and overview of de novo transcriptome
div.p: According to our previous work, the extraction of high-quality jellyfish RNA has proven to be the key step in transcriptome construction; this was particularly true for the Antarctic jellyfish Cyanea sp., which was transported to the laboratory at Shanghai by the 'Xuelong' vessel under −20°C for a long period of more than two months. It is extremely fortunate that the OD260/OD280 value of the extracted sample was 2.03, a value in the middle of the required range of 1.8-2.2, and three distinct bands (28S, 18S and 5S) of the total RNA were clearly exhibited in the electrophoretic lane, indicating that high-quality RNA from the Antarctic jellyfish Cyanea sp. was successfully harvested ( Fig. 2A). A series of subsequent steps, including mRNA purification and fragmentation, cDNA synthesis and library construction, and final Illumina sequencing, were completed.

A total of 59,106,948 raw reads and 8,866,942,200 bases with a GC ratio of 43.72% were obtained. Almost all the values of the bases in the single-base quality distribution map exceeded 20, with a central wide plateau accompanied and two lower sides (Fig. 2B). The graph of the base content distribution showed that the ratios of A, T, C and G were parallel and close after a typical acceptable fluctuation in the initial stage due to the bias of the 6-bp random primers, indicating that the cDNA library and sequencing had good uniformity (Fig. 2C). After removing the adapters and low-quality sequences, a total of 58,221,308 (98.50%) clean reads and 8,475,044,962 (95.58%) clean bases were obtained. De novo assembly was then performed using the software Trinity with three independent modules, Inchworm, Chrysalis and Butterfly, which transformed the clean reads to Contigs, de Bruijn graphs and the final transcripts, respectively. Eventually, a total of 40,468 unigenes were fixed after removing redundancies.

With a BLASTx alignment e-value threshold of 10 −5 , we successfully annotated 12,955 (32.01%) unigenes with the NR database, 10,882 (26.89%) unigenes with the SWISSPROT database, 4951 (12.23%) unigenes with the GO database, and 4901 (12.11%) unigenes with the KEGG database. The NR database is a non-redundant protein sequence database collected by NCBI. In the comparison with the NR database, sequence hits with 40-60% similarity were the most abundant and account for 48.54% of all sequences, whereas hits with < 40% similarity were the next most abundant, with a percentage of 24.68%, followed by the 60-80% similarity sequences, with a percentage of 21.91% (Fig. 2D). All the annotated sequences have low e-values, with the e-value ranges of 0, 0~1e-100, 1e-100~1e-60, 1e-60~1e-45, 1e-45~1e-30, and 1e-30~1e-15 representing 13%, 30%, 19%, 10%, 12%, and 16% of all sequences, respectively ( Fig. 2E). Four cnidarian species, Hydra vulgaris, Exaiptasia pallida, Nematostella vectensis and Acropora digitifera, are the most matched species. Their similarities are 30.06%, 13.51%, 11.24% and 10.98%, respectively (Fig. 2F).

div.head: Transcriptome-based proteome and profile
div.p: In the proteomic analysis, the electrophoretic band was clear, complete and homogeneous, and no protein degradation was observed (Fig. 3A). All raw proteomics MS data were aligned to acquire peptide sequence information and matched to proteins from the constructed transcriptome of the Antarctic jellyfish Cyanea sp. A total of 11,159 peptides and 2630 proteins were matched and harvested after the comparison with the 40,468 unigenes (Fig. 3B). There is a significant negative correlation between peptide count and protein number. The top 10 peptide counts from 1 to 10 have an overall 2413 proteins accounting for a percentage of 91.75%, and the top three protein numbers with peptide counts of 1, 2 and 3 are 955 (36.31%), 452 (17.14%) and 290 (11.03%), respectively (Fig. 3C). In comparison, the molecular weight distribution corresponding to protein numbers can be divided into four sections. The first section, encompassing weights < 10 kDa, has a small number of proteins (83 proteins), while the second section, encompassing weights between 10 and 60 kDa, has the maximal number of proteins, with protein numbers beyond 200 for each histogram. The third section has protein numbers ranging between 50 and 200, with molecular weights of 60-120 kDa, and all the remaining proteins with molecular weights > 120 kDa can be attributed to the fourth section, which has protein numbers < 50 ( Fig. 3D). Consistent with our expectations, the shape of the isoelectric point distribution is 'downbell', in which most of the proteins are distributed between pH 4 and 11, and the maximal protein numbers are beyond 500 at pH 6 and 7 (Fig. 3E).

div.head: GO analysis
div.p: GO analyses of unigenes and proteins were conducted by the software BLAST2GO with default parameters [29] and assigned annotations to three primary GO domains: biological process (BP), cellular component (CC) and molecular function (MF). A total of 771 (29.31%) of 2630 proteins were successfully annotated against the GO database; this percentage is 2.40 times higher than the percentage of the annotated unigenes, with 4951 (12.23%) of the 40,468 unigenes annotated. Only the terms with > 100 unigenes or 10 proteins were selected for further analysis. Among the 21 selected BP terms (Fig. 4A), the number of unigenes drops from 6377 (15.76%) in cellular process to 123 (0.30%) in presynaptic process involved in chemical synaptic transmission (PPICS), while the number of proteins decreases from 959 (36.47%) in cellular process to 1 (0.85%) in biological phase. Although the number of annotated unigenes is much larger than that of annotated proteins, a greater percentage of proteins than unigenes were annotated with BP terms, and the former exhibits similar annotations as the latter, albeit with sharply decreased numbers of sequences for each term, with the same ranking of the top 4 terms, i.e., cellular process, single-organism process, metabolic process and biological regulation. 8, 7, and 5 terms have higher, similar and lower percentages of proteins vs. unigenes, respectively, using 1. The term biological adhesion (2.44) displays a high ratio, probably due to the high distribution of mucus on the jellyfish surface. A total of 14 CC terms were successfully identified (Fig. 4B), with numbers of unigenes and proteins ranging from 7044 (17.40%) in the cell term to 182 (0.45%) in the supramolecular complex term and from 1097 (41.71%) in the cell term to 34 (1.29%) in the synapse part term, respectively. Similar to the distribution of BP terms, the proteins display an overall high proportion and a sharp decreasing tendency. In comparison, all the ratios of proteins to unigenes in the CC terms exceed 1.5; in particular, the values in the top 8 terms that have > 1700 unigenes and 300 proteins are very stable and are close to the overall proteome vs. The overall impression of the CC terms is that the extracellular, membrane-related and intracellular components from the outside to inside of cells display higher (8-9), medium (2.5-4.5) and lower (1.5-2.5) protein to unigene ratios, respectively.

Comparatively, MF had the least (11) selected terms ( Fig. 4C), with numbers of unigenes and proteins ranging from 3677 (9.09%) in binding to 29 (0.07%) in antioxidant activity and from 820 (31.18%) in binding to 15 (0.57%) in antioxidant activity, respectively. Except for the common characterizations of a high protein to unigene ratio and sharp decreasing tendency in the number of proteins vs. unigenes, the much larger quantity of sequences assigned to the top of the 2 terms (> 2900 unigenes and > 550 proteins) than to the rest of the terms (< 650 unigenes and < 90 proteins) is notable. A total of 6 terms with a ratio range of 2-4 occupy the first of the three divided sections of MF terms, i.e., binding (3.43), catalytic activity (3.12), transporter activity (2.09), molecular function regulator (2.00), structural molecule activity (3.06), and electron carrier activity (3.90). The second section has 4 terms with a range ratio of 0.6-1.1, including molecular transducer activity (0.62), signal transducer activity (1.01), nucleic acid binding transcription factor activity (0.74), and transcription factor activity/ protein binding (0.93). Interestingly, the largest value (7.99) is associated with the term antioxidant activity, which occupies the last section.

div.head: KEGG analysis
div.p: A number of 4901 (12.11%) unigenes and 841 (31.98%) proteins were annotated against the KEGG database with the online automated annotation system KAAS (KEGG Automatic Annotation Server) (http:// www.genome.jp/tools/kaas/). Therefore, the overall ratio of proteins vs. unigenes is 2.64, slightly higher than the value of 2.40 from GO analysis. Six domains divided the first level according to the KEGG classification, and the ratios of proteins vs. unigenes are all near 1, except for the ratio of the metabolism and genetic information processing terms, with higher values of 1.97 and 1.61, respectively (Fig. 5A). In the cellular processes category, the terms transport and catabolism (1.64), cellular community-eukaryotes (1.37), and cell motility (1.28) display high ratios, while the value of the term cell growth and death is only 0.69 (Fig. 5B). Since the term signal transduction occupies most of the matched proteins in the domain of environmental information processing, the ratio of 0.94 of signal transduction almost entirely represents the overall value of 0.96 of the domain (Fig. 5C). Except for the term replication and repair, with a ratio of 0.91, all three other terms, i.e., translation, folding, sorting and degradation and transcription, have high values of 1.59, 2.05 and 1.52, leading to a large value of 1.61 for the genetic information processing domain (Fig. 5D). The ratio of the human disease domain is 1.19, for which the term cardiovascular disease displays the largest value of 1.68, while the term substance dependence has the smallest value of 0.43 (Fig. 5E). Except for glycan biosynthesis and metabolism, with the lowest value of 0.67, and lipid metabolism and nucleotide metabolism, with values close to 1, all other terms display ratios > 1.75, leading to metabolism to have the highest value (1.97) among all six domains (Fig. 5F). In contrast, the domain organismal systems possess a small value of 0.90 in the first KEGG classification; within this domain, the smallest value of 0.52 is for the term sensory system, and the highest value of 1.64 is for the term excretory system (Fig. 5G).

A total of 372 pathways matched by unigenes and 328 pathways matched by proteins were successfully annotated with third-level terms against KEGG databases. The top 3 pathways with matched unigenes are ribosome (440, 1.09%), pathways in cancer (386, 0.95%) and human papillomavirus infection (361, 0.89%), whereas the top 3 protein-matched pathways are carbon metabolism (34, 1.29%), RNA transport (33, 1.25%) and endocytosis (31, 1.18%). According to the protein to unigene ratios, the top 3 pathways with > 100 unigenes are proteasome(7.39), TCA cycle (4.68) and beta-alanine metabolism Fig. 4. Comparative Gene Ontology (GO) analysis of unigenes and proteins. The results are summarized in three main categories: (A) biological process (BP); "mop", "cco…" and "ppii…" in the figure is actually represented as a "multicellular organismal process" "cellular component organization or biogenesis" and "presynaptic process involved in chemical synaptic transmission", respectively. (B) cellular component (CC), and (C) molecular function (MF); "nucleic acid binding…" and "transcription factor activity…" in the figure is actually represented as "nucleic acid binding transcription factor activity" and "transcription factor activity, protein binding", respectively. For each category, the abundant level-2 GO terms are comparatively displayed with data for proteins vs. unigenes. The abscissa shows the annotated terms. The main ordinate corresponds to the histogram that indicates the ratio of proteins (unigenes) in each term to the total number of proteins (unigenes) identified, while the sub-ordinate represents the ratios of proteins vs. unigenes. 4.45). Furthermore, four pathways were matched only in the transcriptome but not in the proteome. They are human papillomavirus infection (361, 0.89%) pathways were matched only in the transcriptome but not in the proteome. They are human papillomavirus infection (361, 0.89%), cellular senescence (172, 0.43%), necroptosis (129, 0.32%) and Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus infection (117, 0.29%). The top 25 pathways are also ordered by unigene quantity from 440 (1.09%) ribosome unigenes to 205 (0.51%) tight junction unigenes (Fig. 5H); there are 12 pathways with ratios ranging between 0.667 and 1.5, and the ratio values of 7 pathways are higher than 1.5. Only one pathway, human papillomavirus infections, possesses a large number (361, 0.89%) of annotated unigenes without any annotated proteins, thereby displaying a ratio (0) that is lower than 0.667.

div.head: Potential toxin screening
div.p: As the mechanism by which biotoxins impact the human body is a complex issue with many aspects, related research is very important for human society not only for first aid [30] but also for potential treatments of certain diseases [31]. Jellyfish toxins encompass a group of unique and novel proteins with peptide mixtures that have lethal activity, hemolytic activity, cardiovascular toxicity, liver toxicity, neurotoxicity, enzyme activity, etc. [32,33]. According to BLAST annotation of the transcriptome with the NR databases, a total of 145 toxin-related unigenes were successfully screened (Table 1), including 42 metalloproteinases, 12 phospholipases, 10 serine proteases, 5 serine protease inhibitors, 20 toxin-related venoms, and 56 other toxins (Supplementary table 1). Some toxins such as metalloproteinases, phospholipases and serine protease are common constituents in both cnidarian and other toxic organisms such as snakes [34,35]. Other potential toxic components such as 5′-nucleotidase, venom allergen, translationally controlled tumor protein, turripeptide, ryncolin, peroxiredoxin and L-amino-acid oxidase activity were also detected. Meanwhile, a number of 29 toxins from a combined analysis of transcriptome and proteome of BD-4 was successfully screened against the Swissprot toxin database. On the whole, we found 6 metalloproteinases, 4 phospholipases, 2 serine proteases, 1 serine protease inhibitor, 7 toxin-related venom and 9 other toxins. Comparatively, the number of potential toxin protein sequences in the proteome was less than the number of potential toxin gene sequences in the transcriptome.

div.head: Metalloproteinase activity
div.p: It is not surprising that sequences with potential metalloproteinase activity were identified because metalloproteases have been found not only in jellyfish [8] but also in other venomous animals [36,37]. In this study, we scanned 7 metalloproteinases that were annotated in both the proteome and transcriptome and could be classified as matrix metalloproteinase (MMP), A disintegrin and metalloproteinase with thrombospondin motif (ADMTM), A disintegrin and metalloproteinase domain-containing protein (ADAM), zinc metalloproteinase, or metalloproteinase. We selected two sequences predicted as MMP, Cluster-5977.0 and Cluster-3883.8523, for further analysis. A model MMP (pdb ID: 5UE3|A) was utilized to perform the sequence alignment ( Fig. 6A) and 3D modeling (Fig. 6B). Both predicted MMPs displayed a relatively conserved astacin-like subfamily segment with a strict HEXXHXXGXXH zinc-binding site/active site [38,39]. In addition, the 4 parallel β-sheets and the six α-helices were similar in structure (Fig. 6B). In Cluster-5977.0, the main structural variations contained a turn in 77 YLL 81 , (Fig. 6C).

The model ADMTM (pdb ID: 5GHM1|A) was utilized to perform the sequence alignment ( Fig. 7A) and 3D modeling (Fig. 7B). In Cluster-3883.44, the main structural variations were a coil in 222 PGEF 227 and 241 NNGB 246 , a coil-turn-coil in 160 RFVKETWSN 170 ， 200 RRHIKC 207 and 262 ACTVT 268 , a helix-turn-sheet in 172 SKPCGVGIQ 201 , a sheet-turn-coil in 208 ADSENVAK 217 and a helix-turn in 249 YQWT 258 . In Cluster-3883.2436, the main structural variations were a turn in NG 180 and 271 DR 274 , a coil in 286 EYD 290 . a sheet-coil in 192 VPW 195 , a coil-turn in 254 LNS 258 . Two sequences, Cluster-3883.44 and Cluster-3883.2436, displayed two sequences that were evolutionally close to sequence XP012563859 from H. vulgaris and Pocillopora damicornis, respectively, in cnidaria (Fig. 7C).

div.head: Serine protease and serine protease inhibitors
div.p: Serine protease and serine protease inhibitors are widely distributed in marine venomous animals [40]. In this paper, transcripts coding for serine-type endopeptidases and serine-type endopeptidase inhibitors showed rich diversity in the transcriptome of BD-4. Serine proteases show nonconserved substitutions. The gray lines, green bends, blue arrows and red solenoids represent coils, turns, sheets and helices, respectively. Different fragments are framed by red lines. (B) 3D modeling was conducted using the template ADMTM (pdb ID: 5GHM1|A) by SWISS-MODEL and viewed by Discovery Studio 4.5. The colors gray, green, blue and red represent coils, turns, sheets and helices, respectively. (C) Phylogenetic tree constructed using two ADMTM and 10 other sequences from different species using MEGA 7 with the Neighbor-Joining method. Two putative ADMTMs are marked with red circles, Chordata are marked with green circles, cnidaria are marked with blue circles, Hemichordata are marked with pink circles, and Ecdysozoa are marked with yellow circles. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) affect widespread components of the coagulation cascade [41]. Furthermore, serine protease inhibitors can block the activity of trypsin, display potent activity, block potassium channels, and impair the motility of human glioblastoma cells [42,43]. We scanned 2 serine proteases and a serine protease inhibitor that were annotated by both the proteome and transcriptome. We selected two sequences predicted as serine proteases: Cluster-3883.11579 and Cluster-3883.4328, for further analysis. A model serine protease (pdb ID: 5CE1|A) was utilized to perform the sequence alignment ( Fig. 8A) and 3D modeling (Fig. 8B) (Fig. 8C). The percent identity of the C. capillata sequence was the highest at 70.89. This is consistent with the first part of the study, indicating, BD-4 is Cyanea sp.

div.head: The jellyfish BD-4 is identified as Cyanea sp.
div.p: Jellyfish are typified as free-swimming marine animals with delicate The gray lines, green bends, blue arrows and red solenoids represent coils, turns, sheets and helices, respectively. Different fragments are framed by red lines. (B) 3D modeling was conducted using the template serine protease hepsin (pdb ID: 5CE1|A) by SWISS-MODEL and viewed by Discovery Studio 4.5. The colors gray, green, blue and red represent coils, turns, sheets and helices, respectively. (C) Phylogenetic tree constructed using two putative serine proteases and 10 other sequences from different species using MEGA 7 with the Neighbor-Joining method. Two putative serine proteases are marked in red circles, Chordata are marked in green circles, and cnidaria is marked in blue circles. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) soft bodies in the phylum cnidaria. They are found in coastal water zones worldwide and have attracted great attention in recent years because of the sharp increase in their population, which has led to high damages to marine ecological environments and human health. A jellyfish consists of a gelatinous umbrella-shaped bell and trailing tentacles, which are responsible for locomotion and prey capture. The mouth/anus of the gastric pouch is located at the base of the bell and surrounded by oral arms. In this study, the Antarctic soft-bodied creature contained transparent circular umbrella, tentacles, oral arms and a brown gastric pouch and was therefore identified as a type of jellyfish based on morphological characteristics.

Except for the gold standard of 70% sequence similarity between genomes using DNA-DNA reannealing methods to identify species, the most commonly used method for species identification is sequence homology among highly conserved molecules with "housekeeping" functions, e.g., 16S rRNA and the CO1 gene. Usually, a 97% sequence homology between the conserved molecules corresponds to 70% genome similarity. Interestingly, the most aligned CO1 gene sequence, with an identity of 98.90%, was not from jellyfish but was from a species of Molluscusca Cf. Because the sample is definitely a type of jellyfish on the basis of morphological characterization, we explained this high match as the result of horizontal gene transfer, which is not common but can occur between different species and plays an important role in the evolution of both prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Although the similarity between the BD-4 CO1 and other jellyfish CO1 sequences was < 85% at the gene level in the BLASTn comparison, we found that the similarity was > 97% at the protein level in the BLASTx, comparison, and a total of 22 CO1 sequences among the top 100 aligned sequences were from Cyanea. Therefore, the captured organism was identified as an Antarctic jellyfish Cyanea sp..

div.head: Comparative analysis of transcriptomics and proteomics
div.p: Both transcriptomic and proteomic analyses are common methods for studying jellyfish [44,45]. Proteomes present expressed proteins or peptides but limited information, while transcriptomes show more potential details of RNA sequences. Not all RNA sequences will be clearly translated into functional proteins or peptides, so in mechanistic studies, extra experimentations are often required to verify that the RNA of interest is translated into proteins in vivo. In the absence of a genome, de novo assembly of full-length transcripts is a very useful tool in the analysis of the transcriptomes from organisms. Previously, the transcriptome of the venom-producing jellyfish C. nozakii has a total of 40,434 detected unigenes, with the lengths ranging from 201 bp to 31,140 bp, and 1556 homologous proteins were identified in its proteomics analysis. A total of 13,041 unigenes and 801 proteins were annotated and classified by GO analysis while 11,253 unigenes and 959 proteins were classified as associated with KEGG pathways [46]. Venom-related sequences of the scyphozoan jellyfish Chrysaora fuscescens, which has > 23,000 contigs, were annotated in a tentacle transcriptomics analysis through de novo assembly. A total of 163 proteins were mostly functionally grouped as toxin-like proteins, enzymes and structural proteins [35]. In the current study, A total of 4951 (12.23%) of 40,468 unigenes from transcriptome and 771 (29.31%) of 2630 proteins from proteome were successfully annotated against the GO ananlysis, while 4901 (12.11%) unigenes and 841 (31.98%) proteins were annotated against the KEGG database, which is consistent with those parameters of transcriptomics and proteomics from other jellyfish.

div.head: Jellyfish toxins are a rich library for the discovery of novel bioactive compounds
div.p: Animal toxins have high selectivity and specificity for molecular targets and have been considered innovations for the development of new drugs to treat several diseases, such as chronic pain, hypertension, thrombosis and cancer [47]. Jellyfish, which includes species involved in the development of marine drugs, produces a complex mixture of compounds that improve the defensive actions of jellyfish [48]. For example, the box jellyfish C. fleckeri was screened for potential toxins, including metalloproteinase, alpha-macroglobulin domain containing protein, CRISP proteins and turripeptide-like protease inhibitor. Several pore-forming toxins including CfTX-1/2 and CfTX-A/B in C. fleckeri [10], CaTX-A in Carybdea alata [49], CrTX-A/B in Carybdea rastoni [50], and CqTX-A in Chiropsalmus quadrigatus [51] were identified from Cubozoa. Scyphozoa produces toxins as well. By a combination of transcriptomics and proteomics, 27 proteins homologous to toxins were identified from the jellyfish C. nozakii, including phospholipase A2, zinc metalloproteinase-disintegrin, serine protease inhibitor, plancitoxin-1 and alpha-latrocrustotoxin-Lt1a [46]. Transcripts from the jellyfish C. capillata also resembled molecules with potential toxic activities, including cnidarian CfTX-like toxins with hemolytic activity, plancitoxin-1, venom toxin-like peptide-6, histamine-releasing factor, neprilysin, dipeptidyl peptidase 4, vascular endothelial growth factor A, angiotensin-converting enzyme-like and endothelin-converting enzyme 1like proteinse [8,52,53]. In this study, we have successfully identified 145 toxin-related unigenes and 29 toxin-related proteins, such as metalloproteinases, phospholipases, serine proteases, serine protease inhibitor, venom allergen, venom factor, peroxiredoxin, dipeptidyl peptidase 4, turripeptide and chymotrypsin-like. Compared with those from the terrestrial organisms or tropical marine species, the toxins from BD-4 are highly speculated to fit and play the maximal activities through the long term evolution by cold environments, therefore displaying the specific application as a rich library for the discovery of novel bioactive compounds suitable for cold environment.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this work, we first extracted and sequenced the DNA of the MT-CO1 in a polar jellyfish BD-4, performed the phylogenetic sequence analysis, and identified it as an Antarctic jellyfish Cyanea sp. Following de novo sequencing, assembly and alignment of transcriptome, a total of 40,468 unigenes were fixed. We also successfully annotated 12,955 (32.01%) unigenes with the NR database, 10,882 (26.89%) unigenes with the SWISSPROT database, 4951 (12.23%) unigenes with the GO database, and 4901 (12.11%) unigenes with the KEGG database. In the proteomic analysis, a total of 11,159 peptides and 2630 proteins were matched and harvested after the comparison with the transcriptome. A number of 771 (29.31%) and 841 (31.98%) proteins were annotated against the GO and KEGG database, respectively. Moreover, a number of 29 toxic proteins matched from the 145 toxin-related unigenes were successfully screened, including 6 metalloproteinases, 4 phospholipases, 2 serine proteases, 1 serine protease inhibitor, 7 toxin-related venom and 9 other toxins. Our study is the first to identify an Antarctic jellyfish Cyanea sp. with de novo transcriptomics and proteomics, and these data can further serve as a public database for the identification of potential polar jellyfish-derived lead compounds that is suitable for the cold environment.

5-and 0.667-fold changes (FCs) as the high and low thresholds. Three characterizations are observed: (1) For BP terms with a high number of matched proteins (unigenes), such as cellular process (2.31), single-organism process (1.85) and metabolic process (2.21), the ratios of proteins to unigenes are closer to the overall value 2.40 of the ratio of proteome vs. transcriptome, while terms with a small number of annotated proteins (unigenes) show variable ratios. (2) Terms with rapid functional protein consumption have a high mRNA accumulation and therefore display lower protein to unigene ratios; such terms include reproduction (0.48), reproductive process (0.60), locomotion (0.62), growth (0.21), behavior (0.49), and biological phase (0.05). The terms related to development, signaling and organism process show similar ratios of proteins to unigenes. (3)

transcriptome ratio of 2.40; these terms include cell (2.40), cell part (2.39), organelle (2.34), organelle part (2.35), membrane (2.51), macromolecular complex (2.52), membrane-enclosed lumen (2.38), and membrane part (3.16), indicating that proteins involving cellular compartmentation and distribution have a stable ratio of translation from unigenes. In the following 6 terms, the ratiovalues fluctuate sharply: the extracellular region (9.70) and extracellular region part (8.90) terms display the highest ratios, the cellular junction (4.60) and supramolecular complex (3.47) terms show intermediate ratios, and the synapse (1.67) and synapse part (1.65) terms have the lowest ratios.
